history-usa.question: Who was the first President of the United States?
history-usa.explanation: George Washington served as the first President from 1789 to 1797.
history-usa.hint: His face is on the one-dollar bill.

history-usa.question: In what year did the United States declare its independence?
history-usa.explanation: The Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Continental Congress on July 4, 1776.
history-usa.hint: The year a famous document was signed.

history-usa.question: Which major event is considered the start of the American Civil War?
history-usa.explanation: The Battle of Fort Sumter in April 1861 is generally considered the first engagement of the Civil War.
history-usa.hint: The name of a fort in South Carolina.

history-usa.question: Who was the first person to sign the Declaration of Independence?
history-usa.explanation: John Hancock signed his name first and largest so that King George III could read it without his spectacles.
history-usa.hint: His signature is the largest one on the document.

history-usa.question: What famous speech was given by Martin Luther King Jr. in 1963?
options: 'Give Me Liberty or Give Me Death'
'Ask Not What Your Country Can Do for You'
history-usa.explanation: The 'I Have a Dream' speech was delivered during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

history-usa.question: Who was the only U.S. President to serve more than two terms?
history-usa.explanation: Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected to four terms, serving from 1933 to 1945.
history-usa.hint: He served during the Great Depression and World War II.

history-usa.question: What year was the Louisiana Purchase finalized?
history-usa.explanation: The Louisiana Purchase was a land deal between the United States and France in 1803.
history-usa.hint: It was during Thomas Jefferson's presidency.

history-usa.question: Who wrote 'The Star-Spangled Banner'?
history-usa.explanation: Francis Scott Key wrote the lyrics to the U.S. national anthem during the War of 1812.
history-usa.hint: His last name is a type of key.

history-usa.question: The first permanent English settlement in North America was...
history-usa.explanation: Jamestown was founded in the Virginia Colony in 1607.
history-usa.hint: Its name is a combination of jam and town.

history-usa.question: In what decade did the United States land on the moon?
history-usa.explanation: Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed on the moon on July 20, 1969, during the Apollo 11 mission.

history-uk.question: Who was the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom?
history-uk.explanation: Margaret Thatcher, also known as the 'Iron Lady,' served as Prime Minister from 1979 to 1990.

history-uk.question: What monarch ruled Britain during the time of the Spanish Armada?
history-uk.explanation: The Spanish Armada was defeated in 1588 during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I.
history-uk.hint: She was known as 'The Virgin Queen.'

history-uk.question: What was the name of the ship that brought the Pilgrims to America?
history-uk.explanation: The Pilgrims sailed on the Mayflower from Plymouth, England, to the New World in 1620.
history-uk.hint: Its name is a type of flower.

history-uk.question: Who was the last king of the House of Tudor?
history-uk.explanation: Edward VI, the son of Henry VIII, was the last male monarch of the House of Tudor.
history-uk.hint: The son of a famous king.

history-uk.question: Which war was fought between the Houses of Lancaster and York?
history-uk.explanation: The War of the Roses was a series of civil wars for control of the throne of England.

history-uk.question: In what year did the Great Fire of London occur?
history-uk.explanation: The Great Fire of London started on September 2, 1666, and destroyed much of the city.

history-uk.question: Who was the British monarch during World War II?
history-uk.explanation: King George VI reigned from 1936 until his death in 1952, including the entirety of World War II.
history-uk.hint: He was the father of the current Queen.

history-uk.question: The Battle of Hastings in 1066 led to the conquest of England by which group?
history-uk.explanation: The Normans, led by William the Conqueror, defeated the Anglo-Saxons at the Battle of Hastings.
history-uk.hint: They were from a region of France.

history-uk.question: What was the name of the British passenger liner sunk by a German U-boat in 1915?
history-uk.explanation: The sinking of the RMS Lusitania was a major factor in the United States' decision to enter World War I.
history-uk.hint: The first four letters are the same as a type of flower.

history-uk.question: Who was the monarch during the Victorian Era?
history-uk.explanation: The Victorian Era is named after Queen Victoria, who reigned from 1837 to 1901.
history-uk.hint: The era's name is in the question.

history-france.question: In what year did the French Revolution begin?
history-france.explanation: The French Revolution began with the storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789.
history-france.hint: The year a famous prison was stormed.

history-france.question: Who was the French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution?
history-france.explanation: Napoleon Bonaparte crowned himself Emperor of France in 1804.
history-france.hint: He was a famous military general.

history-france.question: What famous landmark in Paris was completed in 1889 for the World's Fair?
history-france.explanation: The Eiffel Tower was built as the entrance arch for the 1889 World's Fair.
history-france.hint: Its name comes from its engineer.

history-france.question: Who was the French king executed during the French Revolution?
history-france.explanation: King Louis XVI was found guilty of treason and was executed by guillotine in 1793.

history-france.question: What was the name of the famous prison stormed during the French Revolution?
history-france.explanation: The storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, is a symbolic event of the revolution.

history-france.question: Joan of Arc was a key figure in which war?
history-france.explanation: Joan of Arc was a military leader who led the French army to victory against the English during the Hundred Years' War.
history-france.hint: A long war between France and England.

history-france.question: What treaty officially ended the Napoleonic Wars?
history-france.explanation: The Treaty of Paris, signed in 1815, officially ended the Napoleonic Wars and exiled Napoleon to the island of Saint Helena.
history-france.hint: Named after the capital of France.

history-france.question: What French monarch was known as the 'Sun King'?
history-france.explanation: Louis XIV, who reigned from 1643 to 1715, was known as the 'Sun King' and was a major patron of the arts.
history-france.hint: He built the Palace of Versailles.

history-france.question: Which French explorer founded the city of Quebec?
options: René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle
history-france.explanation: Samuel de Champlain founded Quebec City in 1608 and is known as the 'Father of New France.'
history-france.hint: His last name sounds like a kind of bubbly drink.

history-france.question: What was the official slogan of the French Revolution?
options: 'All for One, and One for All'
history-france.explanation: The slogan 'Liberté, égalité, fraternité' (Liberty, Equality, Fraternity) became the rallying cry of the French Revolution.

history-ancient-rome.question: Who was the first emperor of Rome?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Augustus, born Octavian, was the founder of the Roman Empire and its first emperor.
history-ancient-rome.hint: His name comes from the month of August.

history-ancient-rome.question: What volcano famously erupted in 79 AD, burying the city of Pompeii?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Mount Vesuvius's eruption in 79 AD destroyed the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum.

history-ancient-rome.question: The Colosseum was built for what purpose?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: The Colosseum was an amphitheater used for gladiator contests and public spectacles.

history-ancient-rome.question: Who was the legendary founder of Rome?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: According to legend, Rome was founded by twins Romulus and Remus, with Romulus eventually becoming the first king.
history-ancient-rome.hint: His name is very similar to the city's name.

history-ancient-rome.question: What famous Roman general was assassinated on the Ides of March?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Julius Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators on March 15, 44 BC.

history-ancient-rome.question: What was the name of the elite Roman force tasked with guarding the emperor?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: The Praetorian Guard served as the personal bodyguards of the Roman emperors.
history-ancient-rome.hint: Their name sounds like a type of court.

history-ancient-rome.question: What did the Romans call the Mediterranean Sea?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Mare Nostrum, which means 'Our Sea,' was the Roman name for the Mediterranean Sea.
history-ancient-rome.hint: It literally means 'Our Sea' in Latin.

history-ancient-rome.question: What was the name of the Roman Senate's meeting place?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: The Curia Julia was the Senate House in the Roman Forum.

history-ancient-rome.question: What Roman structure was famous for carrying water over long distances?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Aqueducts were Roman constructions used to supply water to cities.

history-ancient-rome.question: Which Roman emperor made Christianity the state religion of the empire?
history-ancient-rome.explanation: Constantine the Great issued the Edict of Milan in 313 AD, which legalized Christianity, and he later made it the state religion.
history-ancient-rome.hint: He was the first Roman emperor to convert to Christianity.

history-ancient-greece.question: What was the name of the Greek city-state known for its military power?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: Sparta was a powerful city-state known for its highly trained army and its rivalry with Athens.
history-ancient-greece.hint: The movie '300' is about this city-state.

history-ancient-greece.question: Who was the Greek philosopher who taught Plato and was sentenced to death by hemlock?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: Socrates is considered one of the founders of Western philosophy. He was executed for corrupting the youth and impiety.

history-ancient-greece.question: Which Greek hero famously slayed the Minotaur?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: According to Greek mythology, Theseus entered the Labyrinth to kill the Minotaur, a half-man, half-bull monster.

history-ancient-greece.question: What was the name of the war between Athens and Sparta?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: The Peloponnesian War was a long and devastating conflict that pitted Athens against the Spartan-led Peloponnesian League.
history-ancient-greece.hint: It was named after a Greek peninsula.

history-ancient-greece.question: Who was the Greek god of the sea?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: Poseidon was one of the twelve Olympian gods, presiding over the sea, storms, and earthquakes.

history-ancient-greece.question: The first Olympic Games were held in which city?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: The ancient Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions held every four years in the sanctuary of Olympia.
history-ancient-greece.hint: The name of the city is in the name of the games.

history-ancient-greece.question: Who was the Greek mathematician known for his theorem about right-angled triangles?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: The Pythagorean theorem, which states that the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides, is named after him.
history-ancient-greece.hint: He also founded a religious movement.

history-ancient-greece.question: What was the name of the famous Greek temple dedicated to the goddess Athena?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: The Parthenon is a former temple on the Athenian Acropolis, dedicated to the goddess Athena.

history-ancient-greece.question: Who was the Macedonian king who created a vast empire stretching from Greece to India?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: Alexander the Great's military campaigns led to the conquest of a massive empire in the 4th century BC.
history-ancient-greece.hint: He was 'the Great' for a reason.

history-ancient-greece.question: What form of government was invented in Athens?
history-ancient-greece.explanation: The word 'democracy' comes from the Greek words 'demos' (people) and 'kratos' (rule).

movies.question: In what year was the first 'Star Wars' movie released?
movies.explanation: 'Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope' was released in 1977, changing the landscape of cinema forever.
movies.hint: The same year the first 'Rocky' movie won Best Picture.

movies.question: Who directed the movie 'Jaws'?
movies.explanation: Steven Spielberg's direction of 'Jaws' established him as a major Hollywood filmmaker.

movies.question: What is the name of the hobbit who carries the One Ring in 'The Lord of the Rings'?
movies.explanation: Frodo Baggins is the main protagonist of the trilogy and the bearer of the One Ring.
movies.hint: His last name is a type of bag.

movies.question: Which film won the first Academy Award for Best Picture?
options: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans
movies.explanation: The 1927 silent film 'Wings' was the inaugural winner of the Best Picture award.
movies.hint: It was a silent war movie.

movies.question: What actress starred as Dorothy in 'The Wizard of Oz'?
movies.explanation: Judy Garland became an iconic star for her role as Dorothy Gale in the 1939 classic film.
movies.hint: She was also the mother of Liza Minnelli.

movies.question: In the movie 'The Matrix,' what is Neo's real name?
movies.explanation: Neo's real name is revealed as Thomas Anderson before he is unplugged from the Matrix.
movies.hint: His last name is a common first name.

movies.question: What is the name of the fictional African country in 'Black Panther'?
movies.explanation: Wakanda is a technologically advanced, isolated nation in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

movies.question: Who played the character of the Joker in 'The Dark Knight'?
movies.explanation: Heath Ledger won a posthumous Academy Award for his role as the Joker.
movies.hint: He tragically passed away after filming.

movies.question: The famous line 'I'm going to make him an offer he can't refuse' is from which movie?
movies.explanation: This line is a hallmark of the 1972 classic crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola.
movies.hint: A film about the Corleone family.

movies.question: Which animated movie was the first to be nominated for an Academy Award for Best Picture?
movies.explanation: 'Beauty and the Beast' was the first animated film to be nominated for Best Picture in 1991.
movies.hint: A tale as old as time.

science.question: What planet is known as the 'Red Planet'?
science.explanation: The iron oxide on the surface of Mars gives it a reddish appearance, leading to its nickname.
science.hint: It's the fourth planet from the sun.

science.question: What is the chemical symbol for gold?
science.explanation: The symbol 'Au' comes from the Latin word for gold, 'aurum'.

science.question: What is the name of the process by which plants make their own food?
science.explanation: Photosynthesis is the process that converts light energy into chemical energy.

science.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
science.explanation: The skin is the largest organ of the integumentary system, covering the entire body.

science.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
science.explanation: Mitochondria are organelles that generate most of the chemical energy needed to power the cell's biochemical reactions.

science.question: What is the boiling point of water in Celsius?
science.explanation: Water boils at 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

science.question: What force keeps planets in orbit around the sun?
science.explanation: Gravity is the fundamental force of attraction between objects with mass, which holds the solar system together.
science.hint: It's what keeps you on the ground.

science.question: Which is the smallest planet in our solar system?
science.explanation: Mercury is the smallest of the eight planets in our solar system.
science.hint: It's also the closest to the sun.

science.question: What is the main gas that makes up the air we breathe?
science.explanation: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of the Earth's atmosphere, while oxygen makes up about 21%.

science.question: What is a group of stars, dust, and gas held together by gravity?
science.explanation: A galaxy is a massive system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter bound together by gravity.

general.question: What is the capital of France?
general.explanation: Paris is the capital and most populous city of France.
general.hint: It's known as the 'City of Love'.

general.question: What is the largest country in the world by land area?
general.explanation: Russia spans over 17 million square kilometers, making it the largest country in the world.

general.question: How many continents are there?
general.explanation: The seven continents are Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, and South America.

general.question: What is the longest river in the world?
general.explanation: The Nile River in Africa is generally considered the longest river in the world.

general.question: What is the main language spoken in Brazil?
general.explanation: Brazil is the only country in South America whose official language is Portuguese.

general.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
general.explanation: The Mona Lisa is a half-length portrait by the Italian Renaissance artist Leonardo da Vinci.

general.question: How many days are in a leap year?
general.explanation: A leap year occurs every four years and has an extra day in February to keep the calendar year in sync with the astronomical year.
general.hint: It's one more than a standard year.

general.question: What is the currency of Japan?
general.explanation: The Japanese Yen is the official currency of Japan.
general.hint: It sounds like a popular food item.

general.question: What is the largest ocean on Earth?
general.explanation: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest of Earth's five oceans.

general.question: What is the highest mountain in the world?
general.explanation: Mount Everest, located in the Himalayas, is the highest mountain above sea level.
general.hint: You have to climb it to be an expert.

music-60s.question: The Beatles' final album released was 'Let It Be', but what was the last one they recorded?
options: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
music-60s.explanation: 'Let It Be' was released in 1970, after the band had broken up, but 'Abbey Road' was the last album they recorded together in 1969.
music-60s.hint: Named after a famous London street crossing.

music-60s.question: Who was the lead singer of The Doors?
music-60s.explanation: Jim Morrison was the iconic and charismatic lead singer of The Doors.
music-60s.hint: He was known as the 'Lizard King'.

music-60s.question: Which of these artists was not part of the '27 Club'?
music-60s.explanation: The '27 Club' is a list of musicians who died at the age of 27.
music-60s.hint: He is still alive.

music-60s.question: What was the name of Elvis Presley's home in Memphis, Tennessee?
music-60s.explanation: Graceland is a famous mansion that served as Elvis Presley's home and is now a museum.
music-60s.hint: It sounds like a place full of grace.

music-60s.question: Which band had a hit song with 'Good Vibrations'?
music-60s.explanation: 'Good Vibrations' was a highly complex and experimental pop song released by The Beach Boys in 1966.
music-60s.hint: They were known for their harmonies and surf rock.

music-60s.question: Who was the lead guitarist of The Who?
music-60s.explanation: Pete Townshend was the primary songwriter and guitarist for the rock band The Who.
music-60s.hint: He often smashed his guitars on stage.

music-60s.question: The famous Woodstock music festival took place in which year?
music-60s.explanation: The Woodstock Music & Art Fair was a legendary music festival held in August 1969.
music-60s.hint: The year of the moon landing.

music-60s.question: Which song by Simon & Garfunkel was featured in the movie 'The Graduate'?
music-60s.explanation: 'Mrs. Robinson' was a huge hit that became synonymous with the film 'The Graduate'.
music-60s.hint: It's about a character in the movie.

music-60s.question: Which singer was known as 'The Queen of Soul'?
music-60s.explanation: Aretha Franklin earned the nickname 'The Queen of Soul' for her powerful voice and gospel-infused style.
music-60s.hint: She's famous for her song 'Respect'.

music-60s.question: What was the title of The Beatles' first album released in the UK?
music-60s.explanation: The album was recorded in a single day and released in 1963 to commercial success.
music-60s.hint: The name of a song on the album.

music-70s.question: Which band released the iconic album 'Hotel California'?
music-70s.explanation: The Eagles' album 'Hotel California' was released in 1976 and is one of the best-selling albums of all time.
music-70s.hint: They were a soft rock band.

music-70s.question: What was the name of the popular disco group known for the song 'Stayin' Alive'?
music-70s.explanation: The Bee Gees' 'Stayin' Alive' was a central song on the 'Saturday Night Fever' soundtrack.
music-70s.hint: Their name is made of two words.

music-70s.question: Which rock band had a hit with the song 'Bohemian Rhapsody'?
music-70s.explanation: 'Bohemian Rhapsody' is a legendary rock opera song from Queen's 1975 album 'A Night at the Opera'.
music-70s.hint: Named after a royal.

music-70s.question: Who was the lead singer of Led Zeppelin?
music-70s.explanation: Robert Plant was the vocalist and lyricist for the influential rock band Led Zeppelin.
music-70s.hint: He also had a solo career.

music-70s.question: What artist released the album 'Rumours' in 1977?
music-70s.explanation: 'Rumours' is the eleventh studio album by the British-American rock band Fleetwood Mac.
music-70s.hint: Their name sounds like a car.

music-70s.question: Which artist released the song 'What's Going On' in 1971?
music-70s.explanation: 'What's Going On' is a protest song by Marvin Gaye that addresses issues of war and social injustice.
music-70s.hint: His last name rhymes with 'say'.

music-70s.question: Who was the legendary guitarist of Pink Floyd?
music-70s.explanation: David Gilmour joined Pink Floyd in 1968 and became a major creative force in the band.
music-70s.hint: He also had a solo career.

music-70s.question: What was the stage name of the musician born Reginald Dwight?
music-70s.explanation: Elton John, a flamboyant rock star, took his stage name in the late 1960s.
music-70s.hint: He wrote the song 'Rocket Man'.

music-70s.question: Which artist released the album 'Tapestry' in 1971?
music-70s.explanation: 'Tapestry' is the second solo studio album by Carole King. It is one of the best-selling albums of all time.
music-70s.hint: Her name sounds like a ruler.

music-70s.question: Which iconic artist released the song 'Rebel Rebel'?
music-70s.explanation: 'Rebel Rebel' is a song by David Bowie from his 1974 album 'Diamond Dogs'.
music-70s.hint: He was known as the 'Starman'.

music-80s.question: What Michael Jackson album, released in 1982, is the best-selling album of all time?
music-80s.explanation: 'Thriller' is a pop masterpiece that solidified Michael Jackson's status as the 'King of Pop'.
music-80s.hint: The name of the album is also a dance.

music-80s.question: Which artist released the song 'Like a Virgin'?
music-80s.explanation: 'Like a Virgin' was a controversial but hugely successful single from Madonna's 1984 album of the same name.
music-80s.hint: Her nickname is 'The Material Girl'.

music-80s.question: Which band had a hit song with 'Sweet Child o' Mine'?
music-80s.explanation: 'Sweet Child o' Mine' is one of the most recognizable rock songs of the 1980s.
music-80s.hint: They had a famous lead guitarist named Slash.

music-80s.question: Who sang the hit song 'I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)'?
music-80s.explanation: 'I Wanna Dance with Somebody' was released by Whitney Houston in 1987 and became an instant classic.
music-80s.hint: She was the star of the movie 'The Bodyguard'.

music-80s.question: What band was known for their music video for 'Take on Me'?
music-80s.explanation: The music video for 'Take on Me' was famous for its use of rotoscoping animation and became an MTV staple.
music-80s.hint: Their name sounds like an exclamation.

music-80s.question: Which band had a hit song with 'Don't Stop Believin'?
music-80s.explanation: 'Don't Stop Believin'' is one of the most enduring rock anthems of all time.
music-80s.hint: Their name is also a trip.

music-80s.question: Who was the lead singer of the band U2?
music-80s.explanation: Bono is the lead vocalist and primary lyricist for the Irish rock band U2.
music-80s.hint: His name is a gift in Latin.

music-80s.question: What song from the movie 'Top Gun' was a number one hit for Berlin?
music-80s.explanation: 'Take My Breath Away' was a romantic ballad that became a signature song for the movie.
music-80s.hint: The name of the song is also a phrase.

music-80s.question: Which artist released the album 'Purple Rain'?
music-80s.explanation: 'Purple Rain' is the sixth studio album by Prince and a classic of the 1980s.
music-80s.hint: The artist is also a symbol.

music-80s.question: What was the name of the popular hair band known for the song 'Every Rose Has Its Thorn'?
music-80s.explanation: Poison was a popular hair band that had a hit with the power ballad 'Every Rose Has Its Thorn'.
music-80s.hint: Their name is a type of liquid.

music-90s.question: Who sang the hit song 'I Will Always Love You' from the movie 'The Bodyguard'?
music-90s.explanation: Whitney Houston's rendition of 'I Will Always Love You' is one of the best-selling singles of all time.
music-90s.hint: She was also the star of the movie.

music-90s.question: Which band released the album 'Nevermind'?
music-90s.explanation: 'Nevermind' launched the grunge music scene into the mainstream and is considered a rock masterpiece.
music-90s.hint: The lead singer was Kurt Cobain.

music-90s.question: What female artist released the hit single 'One Sweet Day' with Boyz II Men?
music-90s.explanation: 'One Sweet Day' spent a record 16 weeks at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
music-90s.hint: She is known for her impressive vocal range.

music-90s.question: What was the name of the band that had a hit with the song 'Losing My Religion'?
music-90s.explanation: 'Losing My Religion' was a massive hit for the alternative rock band R.E.M. in 1991.
music-90s.hint: Their name is an abbreviation for a type of sleep.

music-90s.question: Which band was known for the hit song 'Wonderwall'?
music-90s.explanation: 'Wonderwall' is one of the most recognizable songs from the British rock band Oasis.
music-90s.hint: They were part of the Britpop movement.

music-90s.question: Who was the lead singer of the band Pearl Jam?
music-90s.explanation: Eddie Vedder is the lead vocalist and one of the primary songwriters of the rock band Pearl Jam.
music-90s.hint: He is known for his powerful, baritone voice.

music-90s.question: What was the name of the first Spice Girls single?
music-90s.explanation: 'Wannabe' was the Spice Girls' debut single and an international smash hit in 1996.
music-90s.hint: Its name is a shortened version of 'want to be'.

music-90s.question: Which rapper released the album 'The Slim Shady LP'?
music-90s.explanation: 'The Slim Shady LP' was Eminem's major-label debut album, released in 1999.
music-90s.hint: He is known as the 'Rap God'.

music-90s.question: What was the title of the movie that featured the song 'My Heart Will Go On'?
music-90s.explanation: 'My Heart Will Go On' was the theme song for the 1997 blockbuster film 'Titanic'.
music-90s.hint: A movie about a sinking ship.

music-90s.question: Who was the lead singer of the band No Doubt?
music-90s.explanation: Gwen Stefani rose to fame as the lead singer of the band No Doubt before launching a solo career.
music-90s.hint: Her last name is similar to a country in Europe.

sports-basketball.question: Who holds the record for the most points scored in a single NBA game?
sports-basketball.explanation: Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points in a game against the New York Knicks on March 2, 1962.
sports-basketball.hint: His last name sounds like a royal bedroom.

sports-basketball.question: What is the official name of the 'Hoosiers' basketball team?
sports-basketball.explanation: The 'Hoosiers' is the nickname for the Indiana University athletic teams.
sports-basketball.hint: They're known for a famous rivalry with Purdue.

sports-basketball.question: How many players are on a basketball court for one team during a game?
sports-basketball.explanation: A standard basketball game has five players from each team on the court at a time.
sports-basketball.hint: It's the same number of players on a volleyball team.

sports-basketball.question: Which NBA team has won the most championships in history?
sports-basketball.explanation: The Boston Celtics have won the most NBA championships in history, with 17 titles.
sports-basketball.hint: Their logo is a green clover.

sports-basketball.question: Who is the all-time leading scorer in NBA history?

options: 10 or more in three statistical categories
sports-basketball.answer: 10 or more in three statistical categories
sports-basketball.explanation: A triple-double is a single-game performance where a player accumulates a double-digit number in three of the five statistical categories: points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocked shots.

sports-baseball.question: What is a 'perfect game' in baseball?
options: When a pitcher throws a no-hitter
When a pitcher doesn't allow a runner on base
When a pitcher strikes out every batter
When a team scores a run in every inning
sports-baseball.answer: When a pitcher doesn't allow a runner on base
sports-baseball.explanation: A perfect game is a game in which a pitcher pitches a victory that lasts a minimum of nine innings and in which no opposing player reaches base.
sports-baseball.hint: It's a rare feat for a pitcher.

sports-baseball.question: Who is considered the greatest baseball player of all time?
sports-baseball.explanation: Babe Ruth is widely regarded as the greatest baseball player of all time, famous for his home run hitting.

sports-baseball.question: What is a 'grand slam' in baseball?

A home run that wins the game
A home run with no runners on base
A home run in the bottom of the ninth inning
sports-baseball.answer: A home run with the bases loaded
sports-baseball.explanation: A grand slam is a home run hit with a runner on first, second, and third base.
sports-baseball.hint: It scores four runs at once.

sports-baseball.explanation: The National Pro Fastpitch was the women's professional softball league in the US from 2004 to 2020.

sports-football.answer: When a defender tackles the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage

sports-basketball.explanation: The Boston Celtics have won the most NBA championships in history, with 17 titles.
sports-basketball.hint: Their logo is a green clover.

sports-basketball.question: Who is the all-time leading scorer in NBA history?
sports-basketball.explanation: LeBron James surpassed Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for the all-time scoring record in 2023.
sports-basketball.hint: He is currently a player for the Lakers.

sports-basketball.question: What is a 'triple-double' in basketball?
options: 10 or more in three statistical categories
sports-basketball.answer: 10 or more in three statistical categories
sports-basketball.explanation: A triple-double is a single-game performance where a player accumulates a double-digit number in three of the five statistical categories: points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocked shots.
sports-basketball.hint: It involves at least ten of something, three times.

sports-basketball.question: What is the name of the professional women's basketball league in the US?
sports-basketball.explanation: The Women's National Basketball Association is the premier women's professional basketball league in the United States.
sports-basketball.hint: It sounds like the men's league, with a 'W'.

sports-basketball.question: Who is considered the founder of basketball?
sports-basketball.explanation: James Naismith, a Canadian physical education instructor, invented basketball in 1891.
sports-basketball.hint: His last name sounds like a common last name.

sports-basketball.question: Which NBA player is famous for his 'Skyhook' shot?
sports-basketball.explanation: The 'Skyhook' was a signature shot for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and was notoriously difficult to block.
sports-basketball.hint: His first name is Kareem.

sports-basketball.question: What is the team name for the professional basketball team in Chicago?
sports-basketball.explanation: The Chicago Bulls are an American professional basketball team based in Chicago.
sports-basketball.hint: They're known for having Michael Jordan.

sports-baseball.question: Which MLB team is known as 'The Bronx Bombers'?
sports-baseball.explanation: The New York Yankees' powerful lineup earned them the nickname 'The Bronx Bombers' in the 1930s.
sports-baseball.hint: They play their home games in New York City.

sports-baseball.question: How many innings are in a standard game of baseball?
sports-baseball.explanation: A standard professional baseball game consists of nine innings, unless the game is tied after the ninth.
sports-baseball.hint: One less than a perfect ten.

sports-baseball.question: What is the name of the championship series in Major League Baseball?
sports-baseball.explanation: The World Series is the annual championship series of Major League Baseball.
sports-baseball.hint: It's a series that decides the world champion.

sports-baseball.question: What is a 'perfect game' in baseball?
options: When a pitcher throws a no-hitter
When a pitcher doesn't allow a runner on base
When a pitcher strikes out every batter
When a team scores a run in every inning
sports-baseball.answer: When a pitcher doesn't allow a runner on base
sports-baseball.explanation: A perfect game is a game in which a pitcher pitches a victory that lasts a minimum of nine innings and in which no opposing player reaches base.
sports-baseball.hint: It's a rare feat for a pitcher.

sports-baseball.question: Who is considered the greatest baseball player of all time?
sports-baseball.explanation: Babe Ruth is widely regarded as the greatest baseball player of all time, famous for his home run hitting.
sports-baseball.hint: His nickname was 'The Sultan of Swat'.

sports-baseball.question: What is a 'grand slam' in baseball?
options: A home run with the bases loaded
A home run that wins the game
A home run with no runners on base
A home run in the bottom of the ninth inning
sports-baseball.answer: A home run with the bases loaded
sports-baseball.explanation: A grand slam is a home run hit with a runner on first, second, and third base.
sports-baseball.hint: It scores four runs at once.

sports-baseball.question: What is the name of the professional women's softball league in the US?
sports-baseball.explanation: The National Pro Fastpitch was the women's professional softball league in the US from 2004 to 2020.
sports-baseball.hint: It's an acronym.

sports-baseball.question: What is the official name of the 'Curse of the Bambino'?
options: A curse that affected the Boston Red Sox
A curse that affected the New York Yankees
A curse that affected the Chicago Cubs
A curse that affected the Los Angeles Dodgers
sports-baseball.answer: A curse that affected the Boston Red Sox
sports-baseball.explanation: The 'Curse of the Bambino' was a famous baseball superstition that affected the Boston Red Sox.
sports-baseball.hint: It was named after Babe Ruth.

sports-baseball.question: What is the name of the professional baseball team in Boston?
sports-baseball.explanation: The Boston Red Sox are an American professional baseball team based in Boston.
sports-baseball.hint: Their socks are a certain color.

sports-baseball.question: What is the name of the famous baseball stadium in Chicago?
sports-baseball.explanation: Wrigley Field is a famous baseball stadium in Chicago that is home to the Chicago Cubs.
sports-baseball.hint: It's named after a chewing gum.

sports-football.question: How many players are on the field for one team during an American football game?
sports-football.explanation: A standard American football game has 11 players from each team on the field at a time.
sports-football.hint: The same number as a soccer team.

sports-football.question: What is a 'touchdown' in American football?
options: When a player crosses the goal line with the ball
When a player scores a field goal
When a player intercepts the ball
When a player gets a sack
sports-football.answer: When a player crosses the goal line with the ball
sports-football.explanation: A touchdown is a score in American football that is worth six points.
sports-football.hint: It's the main way to score in the game.

sports-football.question: What is the championship game of the NFL called?
sports-football.explanation: The Super Bowl is the annual championship game of the NFL.
sports-football.hint: It's a big event in February.

sports-football.question: Who is the all-time leader in passing yards in the NFL?
sports-football.explanation: Drew Brees is the all-time leader in passing yards in the NFL, with over 80,000 yards.
sports-football.hint: He played for the New Orleans Saints.

sports-football.question: What is a 'sack' in American football?
options: When a defender tackles the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage
When a defender intercepts the ball
When a defender forces a fumble
When a defender scores a touchdown
sports-football.answer: When a defender tackles the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage
sports-football.explanation: A sack is a play in which a defensive player tackles the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage.
sports-football.hint: It's a way to get a negative yardage.

sports-football.question: What is the name of the professional football team in Kansas City?
sports-football.explanation: The Kansas City Chiefs are an American professional football team based in Kansas City, Missouri.
sports-football.hint: They're known for having Patrick Mahomes.

sports-football.question: What is the name of the professional football league in the US?
sports-football.explanation: The National Football League is the largest professional American football league in the world.
sports-football.hint: It's an acronym.

sports-football.question: What is the name of the famous football stadium in Green Bay?
sports-football.explanation: Lambeau Field is a famous football stadium in Green Bay, Wisconsin, and is home to the Green Bay Packers.
sports-football.hint: It's known as the 'Frozen Tundra'.

sports-football.question: What is the name of the trophy awarded to the Super Bowl winner?
sports-football.explanation: The Lombardi Trophy is the trophy awarded to the winner of the Super Bowl.
sports-football.hint: It's named after a famous coach.

sports-football.question: What is the term for a play in which a defender returns an interception for a touchdown?
sports-football.explanation: A 'pick six' is a play in which a defensive player intercepts a pass and returns it for a touchdown.
sports-football.hint: It's a six-point play.

sports-soccer.question: How many players are on the field for one team during a soccer game?
sports-soccer.explanation: A standard soccer game has 11 players from each team on the field at a time.
sports-soccer.hint: The same number as an American football team.

sports-soccer.question: What is a 'hat-trick' in soccer?
options: When a player scores three goals in a game
When a player scores a goal with his head
When a player scores a goal from a penalty kick
When a player scores a goal from outside the penalty box
sports-soccer.answer: When a player scores three goals in a game
sports-soccer.explanation: A 'hat-trick' is a feat of scoring three goals in a single match.
sports-soccer.hint: It's a term also used in hockey.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the world's largest soccer tournament?
sports-soccer.explanation: The FIFA World Cup is the largest and most prestigious soccer tournament in the world.
sports-soccer.hint: It takes place every four years.

sports-soccer.question: Who is considered the greatest soccer player of all time?
sports-soccer.explanation: Pele is widely regarded as the greatest soccer player of all time, winning three World Cups with Brazil.
sports-soccer.hint: He was a Brazilian legend.

sports-soccer.question: What is a 'penalty kick' in soccer?
options: A free kick from the penalty spot
A free kick from outside the penalty box
sports-soccer.answer: A free kick from the penalty spot
sports-soccer.explanation: A penalty kick is a free kick awarded to a team after a foul is committed inside the penalty box.
sports-soccer.hint: It's a one-on-one shot against the goalkeeper.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the professional soccer league in the US?
sports-soccer.explanation: Major League Soccer is the professional soccer league in the United States and Canada.
sports-soccer.hint: It's an acronym.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the famous soccer stadium in Rio de Janeiro?
sports-soccer.explanation: The Maracanã Stadium is a famous soccer stadium in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and is one of the largest stadiums in the world.
sports-soccer.hint: It hosted the 1950 and 2014 World Cup finals.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the international soccer federation?
sports-soccer.explanation: The International Federation of Association Football is the governing body of international soccer.
sports-soccer.hint: It's an acronym.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the trophy awarded to the World Cup winner?
sports-soccer.explanation: The FIFA World Cup Trophy is the trophy awarded to the winner of the World Cup.
sports-soccer.hint: It's the most prestigious trophy in soccer.

sports-soccer.question: What is the name of the famous soccer player from Argentina?
sports-soccer.explanation: Lionel Messi is an Argentinian soccer player who is widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time.
sports-soccer.hint: His name is in the question.
